answers.answer: Hi!I am sorry to hear about your medical problems. The symptoms of tingling, numbness, dizziness etc are probably due to radiculopathy caused by pressure on spinal nerves in the cervical region. Usually, this respond to treatments like hot and cold compress, stretching exercises, back low impact exercises, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, specially designed corsets, spinal manipulation and traction and epidural injections.Hyperintensities could be due to dilatation of perivascular spaces, demyelination and reduced blood supply. Hence, it can be caused by multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer's or Wilson's Disease, migraine headaches, diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.Please discuss with your doctor. Take care!The medical advice given should not be considered a substitute for medical care provided by a doctor who can examine you. The advice may not be completely correct for you as the doctor cannot examine you and does not know your complete medical history. Hence this reply to your post should only be considered as a guiding line and you must consult your doctor at the earliest for your medical problem.

question: I went to the DR. with numbness and tingling in my R thumb and finger also the whole R side of my face along with blurred  vision a but the blurred vision is only in the morning for about an hour I also get dizzy spells that only last about 2 to 3 seconds and they have an  electrical feeling its almost indescribable.The final impression stated that there are scattered foci of high signal intensity present within the subcortical and deep white matter of the frontal lobes and both external capsules. This is nonspecific. There is no diffusion abnormality or abnormal enhancement.Cord is normal in caliber and signal intensity without abnormal enhancement, central or foraminal narrowing at any level. Minor protrusions and annular measures are present at C4-C5-C6-C7 without central or foraminal narrowing.I have been looking it all up but all I seem to find is MSPLEASE HELPThis discussion is related to/posts/Neurology/Confused-on-MRI-results/show/904024.
title: help with MRI readings
